intro: Narcissus rupicola subsp. guadalupensis, commonly known as the Guadalupe daffodil, is a rare and endemic plant native to the rocky habitats of Texas. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and a single, showy yellow flower with a distinctive crown. The plant typically grows in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid conditions. It is part of the Amaryllidaceae family and is noted for its ornamental value. Due to habitat loss, it is considered threatened and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
